Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Spatial and Temporal Subsidies in Seasonal Environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Aquatic and terrestrial habitats often have major ecological effects on each other. This important aspect of landscape ecology has mostly been investigated in space, between adjacent habitats that are permanently aquatic or terrestrial. This project will investigate the interaction between aquatic and terrestrial habitats in time, in a type of habitat that cycles seasonally between an aquatic and a terrestrial state. Using remnants of the once extensive system of vernal pools in the Central Valley of California, experiments will test how length of flooding and accumulation of nutrients during the aquatic period in winter influence the diversity of plants found in the terrestrial period in summer, and how the thatch these plants leave affects the diversity of aquatic plants and invertebrates in winter.

The broader impacts of this project include training of undergraduate students, outreach to K-12 education, collaboration between institutions, and applications to conservation of biodiversity and endemic species. The project is based at a primarily undergraduate institution that serves underrepresented groups and it will provide research experiences for individual students and material for undergraduate courses. Vernal pools in California are of high conservation priority, and the project will disseminate results to the state and Federal agencies that manage these natural habitats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seasonal variation in precipitation and temperature can result in aquatic and terrestrial habitat occurring sequentially at a single location in the landscape.  Examples include seasonal wetlands, floodplains, and temporary streams and ponds. Ecological research and management tend to focus on the aquatic or terrestrial phases of these ecosystems. The purpose of this research was to examine how aquatic and terrestrial communities affect each other in time and how the length of inundation (hydroperiod) can moderate these interactions in California vernal pools. Hydroperiod, plant thatch (representing the previous year’s terrestrial phase), and nutrients (representing agricultural runoff) were manipulated in a mesocosm experiment for 2 years, and water physico-chemistry, aquatic invertebrates and algae, and terrestrial plant abundance and richness were measured.

This research found that the treatments interacted in complex ways to affect species composition and function.  The aquatic and terrestrial phases affected each other in time, and temporal (thatch from the previous year) and spatial (nutrient addition) effects interacted with the hydroperiod over the 2 years.  For example, thatch addition reduced richness of species emerging from the soil (including 2 endangered species) and increased richness species dispersing into the pools (including mosquitos and insect predators). However, these effects were contingent on hydroperiod length.  Upon desiccation, plant community composition and production were also affected by the interactions between hydroperiod, thatch and nutrients.  Thatch presence from the previous year reduced plant richness, cover, and biomass and eutrophication during the aquatic phase also reduced plant richness, cover, and biomass. The inundation-desiccation cycle across 2 years found strong effects of treatments on intra-annual and inter-annual dynamics.

The results of this project have implications for understanding wetland biodiversity and function in light of climate change.  Predictions can be made about species composition and production with regard to changes in temperature and precipitation patterns.  These results also highlighted the importance of the full inundation-desiccation cycle and effects of aquatic and terrestrial phases on each other for a full understanding of seasonal ecosystems and their management. This grant supported 4 undergraduate research assistants (3 minorities, 2 women), who were trained in taxonomic identification, study design, field and laboratory sampling approaches, data management, and ecological concepts. Several other undergraduate students volunteered on this project receiving similar training. Funds were also used to support the research of a graduate student (minority female) testing the effects of predator density and diversity in vernal pool mesocosms. The PI presented 3 conference talks and an undergraduate student presented a poster based on this project at an international meeting.  A manuscript based on this poster is currently in preparation, including the students as co-authors.  An article and a book chapter were published with support from this grant and 2 manuscripts are currently in preparation based on this research. A program was developed and implemented for a middle school Science Olympiad team at the study site and tours were conducted for 4/5th grade Nature Bowl (CA Dept Fish & Game Program) students and CSUS Earth Day celebrants.

Examples include seasonal wetlands, floodplains, and temporary streams and ponds. Ecological research and management tend to focus on the aquatic or terrestrial phases of these ecosystems. The purpose of this research was to examine how aquatic and terrestrial communities affect each other in time and how the length of inundation (hydroperiod) can moderate these interactions in California vernal pools. Hydroperiod, plant thatch (representing the previous year?s terrestrial phase), and nutrients (representing agricultural runoff) were manipulated in a mesocosm experiment for 2 years, and water physico-chemistry, aquatic invertebrates and algae, and terrestrial plant abundance and richness were measured. This research found that the treatments interacted in complex ways to affect species composition and function. Upon desiccation, plant community composition and production were also affected by the interactions between hydroperiod, thatch and nutrients. The inundation-desiccation cycle across 2 years found strong effects of treatments on intra-annual and inter-annual dynamics.
